We first looked at the suffix -mirri back in Lesson 4, where it meant to have or to possess something. Now, here’s another important use for this same suffix.

And as you might be noticing by now, suffixes in Gupapuyŋu are flexible. They don’t correspond one-to-one with the many prepositions or function words we use in English. Instead, they move across categories of meaning. And the more you study them, the more you realise: at root level, it makes perfect sense why they do.

When we add -mirri not to a noun (as in Lesson 4), but to the quaternary form of a verb, the meaning shifts to refer to the person (or thing) that performs the action of the verb.

Think of it like adding “-er” in English:
work → worker
dance → dancer
write → writer

And the interesting part, if you think about it carefully, this isn’t so different from possession after all. A worker is someone who has work. A dancer is someone who possesses dance, or the art or act of dancing. So we’re still operating inside that same conceptual space. And this is why this kind of system is actually very elegant, it avoids forcing arbitrary category splits like we do in English (noun? verb? agent noun? job title?).

And this reminds me of a similar structure in Turkish. In Turkish, to express the one who does an action, you often add the participle suffix -en / -an to the verb:
yapmak (to do/make) → yapan → the one who does / maker
Very similar to what -mirri does in Gupapuyŋu, turning the action into an identity or role.

djäma (to work) → djämamirri → worker
wukirri (to write) → wukirrimirri → writer
guŋga’yun (to help) → guŋga’yunamirri → helper
buny’tjun (to smoke) → buny’tjunamirri → smoker
ŋatha-bathan (to cook food) → ŋatha-bathanamirri → cook, chef
burrmiḏiyama (to make peace) → burrmiḏiyanhamirri → peacemaker
marŋgikuma (to teach) → marŋgikunhamirri → teacher
gurrupan (to give) → gurrupanamirri → giver
medicine-gurrupan (to give medicine) → medicine-gurrupanamirri → doctor / nurse

Sometimes, instead of -mirri, you’ll see the suffix -yŋu used in exactly this same function.

And you can also combine these new mirri-derived nouns with other nouns, and now you’re into adjective territory:djämamirri miyalk → worker woman → working woman → a woman that works
manaŋinyamirri yolŋu → person who steals → thief
waṉḏinyamirri miyalk → woman that runs → runner
nhänhamirri mala → spectators (those who look)
nhumanamirri waṯu → dog that sniffs/smells around
gaḻ’yunamirri yothu → crawling baby
